description.en: Epistemology is the branch of philosophy concerned with concepts such as knowledge, belief, and rationality. This course will cover some of the traditional problems in epistemology as well as introducing students to issues that arise when we consider the social and applied dimensions of knowledge and rationality. Traditional problems include: What is knowledge? Why is knowledge more valuable than mere true belief? Is knowledge possible? Questions that arise when we apply epistemology to real-world problems include: Can prejudiced beliefs ever be rational? How should we respond to disagreement and when should we voice it? When should you believe that someone consents?

objectives.en: Epistemology is the study of knowledge and related concepts. This course has three objectives: Firstly, to introduce students to the questions that arise when trying to understand knowledge and related concepts. Secondly, to introduce students to the ways that epistemology can help address real-world problems. Thirdly, to provide students with a forum in which to develop their ability to think and talk clearly, constructively, and senstively about these questions.

learning_outcomes.en: Having passed this course, the students will:
- understand some of the key topics, positions, and arguments in contemporary theoretical epistemology
- understand some of the key topics, positions, and arguments in contemporary applied epistemology
- have begun to develop their own views on these topics and an ability to defend their views on these topics
- have developed an improved capacity to identify and construct arguments and engage constructively and sensitively in discourse
